text: All great advice here! <@U01P13NTGG6> consider starting with alternative content channels - but still using for SEO (flipping the line of thinking). Instead of starting with a great SEO blog or gated piece, try creating a video or audio piece like a podcast or talk track. Using the transcript, you can create ebooks/blogs, giving you engaging pieces for sharing/clips/social influence - but written pieces like blogs to achieve your goals of SEO.

text: <@U02TWNFV4RL> — Agreed. Like most things in marketing, it comes down to understanding what channels are going to work best to reach your audience and then focusing in on the 1-2 that work the best vs spreading yourself across too many different things at once.

text:
Hi everyone!

I'm developing a content strategy for a Digital Marketing agency and am looking to conduct interviews with our current clients to get our content fit right from the get go. Does anyone have any insight on what kinds of questions are likely to prompt the best responses and really get to the core of what content they love? Any advice on building a content strategy from scratch is also greatly appreciated, thank you!

text: Hey everyone! I'm working at a SaaS startup. We have a few clients and have case studies from all of them, but they're all over a year old. It doesn't look like we're going to be getting any new ones any time soon. I've been refreshing them periodically to reflect slight changes in messaging etc, but I was wondering if anyone had any ideas for ways to repurpose case studies to extend their lifetime? (nb, most we can't use the company name as they're banks)

elements.text: Hey everyone! I'm working at a SaaS startup. We have a few clients and have case studies from all of them, but they're all over a year old. It doesn't look like we're going to be getting any new ones any time soon. I've been refreshing them periodically to reflect slight changes in messaging etc, but I was wondering if anyone had any ideas for ways to repurpose case studies to extend their lifetime? (nb, most we can't use the company name as they're banks)

text: Are there common themes across the case studies? You can turn those into topic-focused articles like “How 5 Banks Embraced Mobile Bill Pay” or whatever.

elements.text: Are there common themes across the case studies? You can turn those into topic-focused articles like “How 5 Banks Embraced Mobile Bill Pay” or whatever.

text:
What kinds of metrics do ya'll report on each month regarding blog articles and SEO? I'm struggling with how granular I want to get. I know I want to track keyword rankings, organic traffic, and conversions (free trial sign ups). But I also want to show the full story and how all of the metrics work together.

I don't currently have a way to track MQLs, but I'm working on it. in the meantime, the closest way I can tie my team's content efforts to revenue is by showing that we're driving free trial sign ups.

In addition to overall blog performance, I'm also considering a report that shows recent blog posts and how they're performing month over month (like <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_UVZrhNoKnfXnyRCW8BocCyHZrkCola0KfTjq_yhRZg/edit?usp=sharing|this report> <@UJ3K7N8GJ> shared a while back).

Thankful for any insight or even articles/videos you recommend on this topic!

In addition to overall blog performance, I'm also considering a report that shows recent blog posts and how they're performing month over month (like

Thankful for any insight or even articles/videos you recommend on this topic!

text:
I love that idea, Colin.

I ran into this issue at my last company. We had a bunch of old case studies and couldn't get the greenlight to do current ones. So we turned old ones into social & email content. We also used them as examples in blog posts and guest posts on industry publications' blogs.

elements.text:
I love that idea, Colin.

I ran into this issue at my last company. We had a bunch of old case studies and couldn't get the greenlight to do current ones. So we turned old ones into social & email content. We also used them as examples in blog posts and guest posts on industry publications' blogs.

text: I focus 100% on traffic and conversions. Rankings fluctuate too much and you'll lose too much focus wondering why they're going up (or down). The only time I really dive into rankings is if traffic is dropping (to see if we dropped rankings or if it's just that less people are googling it).

elements.text: I focus 100% on traffic and conversions. Rankings fluctuate too much and you'll lose too much focus wondering why they're going up (or down). The only time I really dive into rankings is if traffic is dropping (to see if we dropped rankings or if it's just that less people are googling it).

text: ^we’ve had tons of success with the approach Colin and Dani mentioned. We found a lot of SEO benefit to this - “examples of XYZ” was a lot easier to rank for than the solution on its own (for us it was examples of government affairs strategy being much more manageable than “government affairs strategy” as a keyword). So, we took case studies and turned it into an examples piece and it has consistently sourced revenue. And, now that that piece has driven good engagement, it ranks for the word that was a better fit in the first place of government affairs strategy

And, now that that piece has driven good engagement, it ranks for the word that was a better fit in the first place of government affairs strategy

text:
If you have access to Google My Business insights and you’re providing some level of local SEO, you can share the number of phone calls, website-clicks, directions requests.

I try to share a few ‘wins’ for the month and then a few ‘opportunities’…usually 3-4 each. An example of a win: a blog post or multiple posts that held or holding a featured snippet position(s) (and then show them the snippet too if you’re doing a screenshare). Year over Year sessions are up by 10%, and average time on site is up by 10%.

And then an _opportunity_ might be: organic impressions were down by 12% this month compared to last month. In my experience, clients appreciated the transparency and acknowledgement of an issue that potentially could turn into something bigger. As a provider, we were proactive instead of reactive. I agree with avoiding a convo strictly about ranking changes MoM, but sharing these ‘opportunities’ or areas in need of some improvement generally led to an open, engaging dialogue with the client.

text:
<@UNA88V285>
IMO the best approach is 'Track everything, but report selectively!'

1. Always report on your own work manually – this puts you in the driving seat!
2. DON'T feel like you have to provide exactly the same stats each time. tell a story...
3. The more data points you track privately, the easier it will be to find good news to headline the report
4. If the top-line numbers suffer, being able to provide some background/diagnostics in your reporting shows that everything is Under Control (e.g: 'traffic was down 8% last month, but we've already identified it's because of X keyword shift or issue with Y page')
in any case, don't report everything up the chain automatically (even if you're keeping an eye on it) because it just invites weird obsessions from above like 'I see our 'team' page has dropped 3 places in Google!'

just use the other data to add context and narrative to the top-line numbers as appropriate, e.g:

• Y is going great!! (please disregard X)
• X is bad, but research shows it's bad for all our competitors too
• X is bad - but we've now stopped it getting any worse and might get better again
• X is only bad compared to this weird one-off thing that happened before (but we're working on replicating)
• X is bad but at least we know why

elements.text: IMO the best approach is 'Track everything, but report selectively!'
Always report on your own work manually – this puts you in the driving seat!
DON'T feel like you have to provide exactly the same stats each time. tell a story...
The more data points you track privately, the easier it will be to find good news to headline the report

If the top-line numbers suffer, being able to provide some background/diagnostics in your reporting shows that everything is Under Control (e.g: 'traffic was down 8% last month, but we've already identified it's because of X keyword shift or issue with Y page')

in any case, don't report everything up the chain automatically (even if you're keeping an eye on it) because it just invites weird obsessions from above like 'I see our 'team' page has dropped 3 places in Google!'

just use the other data to add context and narrative to the top-line numbers as appropriate, e.g:
Y is going great!! (please disregard X)
X is bad, but research shows it's bad for all our competitors too
X is bad - but we've now stopped it getting any worse and might get better again
X is only bad compared to this weird one-off thing that happened before (but we're working on replicating)
X is bad but at least we know why

text:
alternatively... you CAN (and I have) share a giant spreadsheet full of extremely granular data, which is 'very transparent' (how nice of you!) but ultimately (and perhaps beneficially...) way too detailed for most other people to understand.

at which point, you'll still need to create another summary document/email/slide deck/etc that explains what's going on, in which case, see above

Good luck!

text:
<https://claraagency.notion.site/Analytics-Dashboard-52cd3be5598a429ca9a920f51b844919|This is the type of dashboard> we use for most of our clients — it's a ton of granular data, and most of them barely glance at it. It looks nice, though. :joy:

In terms of how we report on ongoing data, I try to keep it simple. Because we're working for clients with all variety of internal departments, it varies a lot depending on the client. Some of our clients interpret and investigate their own analytics and don't really talk much to me about it, while others have requested monthly feedback on growth, loss, significant changes, etc.

Like Guy mentions above, for an in-house situation like you're in, you'll still need to interpret that data, and there's no one right way to do it. I also agree with Brendan that traffic and conversions (whether it be email signups, sales, free trials, etc.) are really the biggest things to discuss on an ongoing basis.

One nice thing about Data Studio is that it can use info from a pretty wide variety of sources, so if you've got sales data to implement, you could build it all together to paint that picture in whatever way you think makes the most sense for your internal goals.

elements.text: This is the type of dashboard
we use for most of our clients — it's a ton of granular data, and most of them barely glance at it. It looks nice, though.

In terms of how we report on ongoing data, I try to keep it simple. Because we're working for clients with all variety of internal departments, it varies a lot depending on the client. Some of our clients interpret and investigate their own analytics and don't really talk much to me about it, while others have requested monthly feedback on growth, loss, significant changes, etc.

Like Guy mentions above, for an in-house situation like you're in, you'll still need to interpret that data, and there's no one right way to do it. I also agree with Brendan that traffic and conversions (whether it be email signups, sales, free trials, etc.) are really the biggest things to discuss on an ongoing basis.

One nice thing about Data Studio is that it can use info from a pretty wide variety of sources, so if you've got sales data to implement, you could build it all together to paint that picture in whatever way you think makes the most sense for your internal goals.

text:
Many of our clients have had success driving greater traffic to the story by pulling quotes into social media tiles/campaigns. We also have some clients who maintain older stories because of brand name recognition (clearly not a draw in your instance), but if you are still selling the same products, they are essentially evergreen content as you'll have people looking for stories about that product, regardless of their age. Particularly if their implementation/use case is unique. But might be time to drive a smaller marketing campaign (mention in a newsletter, post on social media) about the story by highlighting the use case. A great example of this is a customer using a content management tool to aid in a digital learning experience (an unconventional application for this particular product). We've driven traffic to the old story because we highlight that use case as an example for the tools' flexibility.

To echo what has been said above, we've had good success with convincing clients who didn't want to spend $ on a case study that a blog post might be just as impactful. Is there an interesting spin/story within the story? If yes, draw that out in a blog post that drives traffic to the longer form case study. I've seen posts stand alone just fine when artfully spun to identify a new angle - but adding it into a series or list of interesting posts is also a great suggestion.

Particularly if their implementation/use case is unique. But might be time to drive a smaller marketing campaign (mention in a newsletter, post on social media) about the story by highlighting the use case. A great example of this is a customer using a content management tool to aid in a digital learning experience (an unconventional application for this particular product). We've driven traffic to the old story because we highlight that use case as an example for the tools' flexibility.

To echo what has been said above, we've had good success with convincing clients who didn't want to spend $ on a case study that a blog post might be just as impactful. Is there an interesting spin/story within the story? If yes, draw that out in a blog post that drives traffic to the longer form case study. I've seen posts stand alone just fine when artfully spun to identify a new angle - but adding it into a series or list of interesting posts is also a great suggestion.

text: Also - depending on the amount of customer content your company has, older stories might get lost if not shared easily with sales. We use slide decks and matrixes to help sales easily identify stories that are an ideal match for their prospects - regardless of age!

elements.text: Also - depending on the amount of customer content your company has, older stories might get lost if not shared easily with sales. We use slide decks and matrixes to help sales easily identify stories that are an ideal match for their prospects - regardless of age!

text:
*Primary Metrics:*
We prefer to report on conversions (signups if product led) or SQO/marketing sourced revenue for everything else through Salesforce.

*For Leading Indicators:*
• Engagement on content (scroll depth, session time, pages/session) as leading indicators that the content is being enjoyed.
• Referring domains
• Qualitative feedback from calls/DMs, etc. where people mention they read a blog post, someone shared it with them, etc.

elements.text: Primary Metrics:
We prefer to report on conversions (signups if product led) or SQO/marketing sourced revenue for everything else through Salesforce.
For Leading Indicators:
Engagement on content (scroll depth, session time, pages/session) as leading indicators that the content is being enjoyed.
Referring domains
Qualitative feedback from calls/DMs, etc. where people mention they read a blog post, someone shared it with them, etc.
